Situation1: Savings are set aside and friends are going this season.
Expectation2: Follow the instructions and guidelines provided by the volunteer coordinator
Situation2: The coordinator emailed a brief suggestion about organizing supplies a different way if time allows.
Story: I’ve been saving for years, setting aside every spare ringgit for Hajj. This year, my friends are finally going, and I feel the pull of joining them, fulfilling a pillar of my faith. My heart aches with longing every time I see their group chat light up with plans and prayers. But as a volunteer at the community center, I also feel a deep responsibility. Just yesterday, our coordinator emailed a suggestion: if I have extra time, could I reorganize the supply room? It’s not a strict order, but I know how much smoother things would run if I did it. I want to help, to be the reliable volunteer everyone counts on. Yet, the thought of missing this year’s Hajj, after all my preparation, fills me with guilt and sadness. I sit at my desk, torn between the sacred journey I’ve dreamed of and the quiet, necessary work my community needs. The expectations press in from both sides, and I can’t see a way to honor both without letting someone down—maybe even myself.
